## alfa-act package

This package provides functionality for implementing rules specified in the [ACT Rules Format](https://www.w3.org/TR/act-rules-format/)<!-- -->.

## Classes

<table><thead><tr><th>

Class


</th><th>

Description


</th></tr></thead>
<tbody><tr><td>

[Audit](./alfa-act.audit.md)


</td><td>

\* I: type of Input for rules \* T: possible types of test targets \* Q: questions' metadata type \* S: possible types of questions' subject.


</td></tr>
<tr><td>

[Cache](./alfa-act.cache.md)


</td><td>



</td></tr>
<tr><td>

[Diagnostic](./alfa-act.diagnostic.md)


</td><td>



</td></tr>
<tr><td>

[Question](./alfa-act.question.md)


</td><td>

\* TYPE is a (JavaScript manipulable) representation of the expected type of answers. It allows oracles and such to act on it. It can be an Enum, an ID, a union of string literals, â€¦ \* SUBJECT is the subject of the question. \* CONTEXT is the context, some extra info added to help the subject make sense. By convention, the context is \*always\* the test target (or potential test target when questions are asked in Applicability). \* ANSWER is the expected type of the answer. \* T is the final result of the question, after transformation. This gives a monadic structure to the question and allow manipulation of the answer without breaking the Question structure. \* URI is a unique identifier for the question.


</td></tr>
</tbody></table>

## Type Aliases

<table><thead><tr><th>

Type Alias


</th><th>

Description


</th></tr></thead>
<tbody><tr><td>

[Interview](./alfa-act.interview.md)


</td><td>

An Interview is either a direct ANSWER; or a question who is ultimately going to produce one, possibly through more questions (aka, an Interview).

The QUESTION type maps questions' URI to the expected type of answer, both as a JavaScript manipulable representation (T), and an actual type (A). The SUBJECT and CONTEXT types are the subject and context of the question.


</td></tr>
<tr><td>

[Oracle](./alfa-act.oracle.md)


</td><td>

\* QUESTION: questions' metadata type; has the shape { URI: \[T, A\] } where URI is the question URI, T a representation of the expected return type, and A the actual return type. Example: { "q1": \["boolean", boolean\], "q2": \["number?", number \| undefined\], }


</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
